channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: Defector: Why I fled North Korea
item.description: When I was young, I thought my country was the best on the planet. I grew up singing a song called "Nothing to Envy." I felt very proud. I thought my life in North Korea was normal, even though when I was 7 years old, I saw my first public execution.

item.title: Anne Frank House praises Bieber visit
item.description: The Anne Frank House in Amsterdam on Monday praised a visit by Justin Bieber, the 19-year-old pop star who sparked outrage with what he wrote in the site's guest book.

item.title: Google in peace deal with Brussels
item.description: Google is bowing for the first time to legally binding constraints on how it presents search results, according to a draft agreement with the EU's top competition authority.

item.title: Pianist sentenced for insulting Islam
item.description: An Istanbul court slapped a world-renowned musician Monday with a 10-month suspended sentence for posting a series of tweets that poked fun at Islamic descriptions of heaven.

item.title: Social media, a new way to rape
item.description: Fifteen-year-old Audrie Pott got drunk at a party and passed out. What happened next, according to her family, was that she was sexually assaulted by multiple young men, who took photos and circulated them in their high school of more than 1,000 students. Not long afterward, Audrie, devastated and hopeless, committed suicide.

item.title: Marathoner: I'll run Boston again
item.description: I ran my eighth Boston Marathon on Monday, the day the bombs went off. We cannot let this terrible tragedy taint this amazing international event or let whoever was behind this evil act win. That's why I will run it again.

item.title: Boston heroes ran to help victims
item.description: Despite the terrible carnage of the Boston bombings, the trauma also brought out the best in people. CNN explores their stories.

item.title: Why Justin Bieber should stay silent
item.description: Dean Obeidallah says a narcissistic comment at the Anne Frank House is one of many from the teen star recently as he tries to prove he's a grown-up. It's not working.

item.title: How MLK became angry black man
item.description: MLK's "Letter from a Birmingham Jail" isn't just a classic. It's a "cry of pain" from an angry black man who was more dangerous than Malcolm X, scholars say.

item.title: Pressure cooker lid found at scene of Boston bombing
item.description: The lid to a pressure cooker thought to have been used in the Boston Marathon bombings that killed three people has been found at the scene, a source tells CNN.

item.title: Chinese student is 3rd victim
item.description: Like thousands of others, the graduate student from China crowded around the finish line at the Boston Marathon to cheer on the runners.

item.title: Mistaken identity adds to family grief
item.description: Patty Campbell worried her daughter Krystle might face amputation after a bomb blast at the Boston Marathon wounded her.

item.title: Witness photos
item.description: CNN iReporters share their photographs and video taken shortly after two bombs exploded at the Boston Marathon.

item.title: Blast victims: A boy, a fan, a student
item.description: They were standing near the finish line, cheering on the runners in the Boston Marathon. It was a beautiful, cool day when two bombs suddenly unleashed chaos and killed three people. As of Tuesday afternoon, identities of two of the three had been made public.

item.title: Boston victim's mother fights tears
item.description: Patty Campbell says Monday's terror attack in Boston doesn't make any sense. Her daughter, Krystle, died in the bombing.

item.title: Obama: I don't think NK has warhead
item.description: President Barack Obama has said he doesn't believe North Korea can fit a nuclear warhead on a missile, casting strong doubt on an alarming assessment disclosed last week by the Pentagon's intelligence arm.

item.title: UK to appeal ruling in Abu Qatada case
item.description: The British government isn't giving up its fight to get radical cleric Abu Qatada out of the UK.

item.title: At least 35 dead in Pakistan quake
item.description: The casualty count from a powerful earthquake that struck near Pakistan's border with Iran now stands at 35 dead and more than 150 wounded, authorities said Wednesday.

item.title: Relief effort scramble after quake
item.description: Dozens dead after a earthquake hit along the border between Iran and Pakistan. CNN's Nic Roberston reports.

item.title: Ricin-tainted envelope sent to senator
item.description: An envelope that tested positive for the deadly poison ricin was intercepted Tuesday afternoon at the U.S. Capitol's off-site mail facility in Washington, congressional and law enforcement sources tell CNN.

item.title: Road side bomb kills 7 in Afghanistan
item.description: A road side bomb killed seven civilians and wounded four others Wednesday in western Afghanistan's Herat province, police said.

item.title: Two rockets lands in southern Israel
item.description: A rocket landed in an open area of the southern Israeli city of Eilat on Wednesday, police said.

item.title: China: 77 cases of bird flu, 16 deaths
item.description: Doctors say the discovery of a 4-year-old carrier of the H7N9 virus who shows no symptoms of the potentially lethal virus is a worrying development that could make the spread of the infection more difficult to monitor.

item.title: 7 die in Venezuela post-poll violence
item.description: Four people have died between Sunday night and Tuesday in post-election protests across Venezuela, the state news agency AVN said.

item.title: 21 executed in Iraq for 'terrorism'
item.description: Iraqi authorities hanged 21 men after they were convicted of terrorism, the nation's Ministry of Justice reported Tuesday.

item.title: Economists' case for austerity attacked
item.description: The intellectual case for fiscal austerity came under attack on Tuesday as two of the world's best-known economists were accused of sloppy statistics.

item.title: Glitch grounds American Airlines
item.description: American Airlines grounded flights nationwide on Tuesday due to problems over several hours with its computerized reservation system.

item.title: Musharraf 'barred from parliament bid'
item.description: Election officials in Pakistan barred former President Pervez Musharraf from running for a parliament seat, his lawyer said Tuesday.

item.title: Cornered thief eats diamond ring
item.description: Caught on cam: Thief swallows ring. Evidence emerges. CNN's Jeanne Moos reports you can bid on this digested diamond.

item.title: Bayern continue domestic domination
item.description: German giants Bayern Munich's march towards domestic domination continues unabated.

item.title: Mourners attend Thatcher funeral
item.description: Amid pomp and ceremony, Britain will say its final farewell Wednesday to Margaret Thatcher -- its first female prime minister and a politician who even in death divides public opinion.

item.title: The Iron Lady's funeral in pictures
item.description: In pictures: Funeral of Margaret Thatcher

item.title: Protesters 'disgusted' at Thatcher
item.description: Anti-Thatcher groups plan to protest along the funeral procession route of the former British prime minister.

item.title: Controversy over cost of funeral
item.description: Former PM Thatcher's funeral could cost more than $15 million with taxpayers picking up the cost. Jim Boulden reports.

item.title: How Korean war might play out
item.description: CNN's Tom Foreman and retired General James Marks map out potential strategies if North Korea attacks South Korea.

item.title: Wearable tech tracks your life
item.description: CNN takes a look at the future of interactive technology.

item.title: The evolution of the cell phone
item.description: CNN's Jim Boulden looks back to the first mobile phone call made 40 years ago.

item.title: Olympic swimmer goes for TV gold
item.description: Anderson Cooper has a preview of Ryan Lochte's upcoming E! reality TV show.

item.title: Are models getting thinner?
item.description: Former fashion editor Kirstie Clements reveals secrets on what models do to stay thin.

item.title: Distraction: Cat walks dog
item.description: Everything is wrong about this. The natural order of things has been disrupted. Run for the hills!

item.title: From townships to the Tour de France
item.description: As driving snow enveloped him and the temperature sank towards zero, Songezo Jim -- a long way from his native South Africa -- took another big step towards realizing his cycling dream. "I would not want to be anywhere else in the world."

item.title: Why we're in 3-speed economic world
item.description: We live in a three-speed economic world, according to the International Monetary Fund. Nations that enjoy the fastest growth include China, India and other emerging countries. Moving at a moderate pace are the United States, finally seeing the light at the end of the 2007 financial crisis tunnel, and Japan, riding a resurgence thanks to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's vow for a 2% inflation target. But economic growth across most of Europe is still growing at a crawl.

item.title: Prisoners run disco in Venezuela
item.description: A Venezuelan prison houses a discotheque for 600 people, sources say. CNN's Rafael Romo reports.

item.title: Why French Jews are leaving country
item.description: With anti-Semitic attacks on the rise, many French Jews are choosing to leave the country, as Jim Bittermann reports.

item.title: Can China become racial melting pot?
item.description: In his first weeks as leader of the world's most populous nation, China's new President Xi Jinping has made frequent reference to an emergent "Chinese Dream," emphasizing prosperity, happiness, and a revitalized national ethos.

item.title: Rails give planes a run for their money
item.description: In Europe, high-speed rail has come to stand for ease and efficiency with point-to-point city center travel where journeys of four hours or less trump airplanes and the hassle of airport security.

item.title: Dental screening that could save your life
item.description: Instead of, "Did I get 8 hours?" we should be asking ourselves, "How well did I sleep?" Not sleeping well could mean you have sleep apnea.

item.title: Does Africa want its 'celebrity saviors?'
item.description: So finally, Madonna's honeymoon with Malawi has ended with a spat. Malawi's minister of education accused Madonna of "bullying officials" and exaggerating the extent of her charity in the country.

item.title: Is now the best time to buy gold?
item.description: With gold officially in a bear market, investors must ask themselves if this is the time to buy. CNN's Jim Boulden recalls a gold bug telling him around 2010 that the precious metal would hit $2000, guaranteed.

item.title: Why Venezuela is so divided
item.description: Some Venezuelans' devotion to Hugo Chavez is unshakeable. But the nation's economy limps along with high inflation and food shortages.

item.title: Post-election violence
item.description: CNN's Paula Newton reports from Venezuela, where violence has broken out amid contested election results.

item.title: Visiting Myanmar: 11 things to know
item.description: Even if you're not planning a trip to Myanmar, take notes and fake it as a Burmese travel expert. Click here for advice on mohawks and more.

item.title: Bourdain on fetal duck egg
item.description: Piers Morgan challenges Anthony Bourdain to a taste test of some bizarre foods. Would you join in the challenge?

item.title: Voices on the street: UK's farewell to Thatcher
item.description: Diehard supporters, tourists and the curious swamped pockets of left-wing protesters to mark the funeral of Margaret Thatcher in London.

item.title: Iron Lady's funeral in photos
item.description: Britain's leaders joined Margaret Thatcher's family in paying tribute to the former prime minister in a funeral ceremony at St. Paul's Cathedral in central London.

item.title: What's new about Boeing's 747-8?
item.description: With new wing and engine designs, the latest version of the legendary jet is the longest commercial plane in the skies. Here's what else is new.

item.title: Inside 'world's best airport'
item.description: CNN's Andrew Stevens explores why Singapore Changi has been voted this year's world's best airport.

item.title: Turn phone into biometric scanner
item.description: A California tech company has launched a tool that turns the iPhone into a powerful biometrics scanning tool.

item.title: 5 blast stories that aren't true
item.description: In the aftermath of dramatic events like Monday's bombing attack at the Boston Marathon, it's a truth of our times that millions of people will get early bits of news via social media.

item.title: Healing wounds one tattoo at a time
item.description: After 16 years of constant surgeries and pain, nothing can compare to the pain of people's stares and comments.

item.title: Marathoner: Why I'll run Boston again
item.description: Sheri Piers crossed the line as the second masters finisher in Boston just before the bombs went off. Here she explains why she'll run it again -- but why it'll be the last time her children cheer from the sidelines.

item.title: Bourdain: Humans 'essentially good'
item.description: Before I set out to travel this world, 12 years ago, I used to believe that the human race as a whole was basically a few steps above wolves.

item.title: Athletes stunned by marathon attack
item.description: Sporting greats including Usain Bolt and LeBron James were quick to tweet messages of shock and sympathy following the deadly blasts in Boston.

item.title: Natural wonders: The top 10
item.description: So very many places to go, yet so little time to pore over the options.

item.title: How does brain respond to music?
item.description: How do our brains respond to music? The quest to dissect exactly what chemical processes occur when we put our headphones on is far from over, but scientists have come across some clues.

item.title: U.S. bombings: Few succeed
item.description: Until Monday's attack on the Boston Marathon, few have succeeded in carrying out terrorist bombings in the U.S. Security analyst Peter Bergen examines why.

item.title: Inside Myanmar with Bourdain
item.description: A sneak peek of the first episode of Anthony Bourdain Parts Unknown from Myanmar -- Watch the full episode Sunday night at 9pm ET/PT only on CNN.

item.title: African doctors curing 'brain drain'
item.description: One in five African-born doctors are working overseas. But many of them are working to improve healthcare back home.

item.title: 'Hurt, anger' part of Thatcher legacy
item.description: Dean of St Paul's, Rev. Dr. David Ison talks to CNN's Max Foster about the public reaction to Margaret Thatcher's death.

item.title: Producer captures Boston blast
item.description: Steve Silva, a Boston Globe web producer, was at the scene and captured the Boston Marathon bombing on video.

item.title: 12-ft alligator caught in yard
item.description: A thousand-pound alligator is found on the lawn of a Hilton Head home.

item.title: Visiting the world's best airport
item.description: CNN's Andrew Stevens explores why Singapore Changi has been voted this year's world's best airport.

item.title: UK without Thatcher?
item.description: Many Britons had awoken with a jolt that morning in April 1982 as news of the invasion on their digital radio alarm clocks left them struggling to believe their ears, oblivious even to the breezy new duet by Paul McCartney and Stevie Wonder that followed.

item.title: Attacks 'can happen anywhere'
item.description: If Sept. 11, 2001 was the day everything changed, then April 15, 2013 was the reminder. "It can't happen here" has been replaced by "it can happen anywhere," says LZ Granderson.

item.title: Nations with most malware are...
item.description: Security threats from mobile malware are on the rise and nearly 95% of targets operate on the Android operating system, according to a new report from NQ Mobile.

item.title: Iran's cartoonists score satire hits
item.description: In 2003, former newspaper editor Ali Reza Eshraghi made a mistake that cost him his freedom: he published a cartoon.

item.title: Is criticism of Justin Bieber fair?
item.description: HLN's A.J. Hammer asks whether Justin Bieber deserves all of the criticism for remarks he made about Anne Frank.

item.title: U.S. drone strikes radicalize Pakistanis
item.description: The Sabaoon School for boys in northern Pakistan is anything but average.

item.title: Acid attack highlights Russian ballet battle
item.description: An acid attack on Bolshoi Theater's artistic director has put the spotlight on a battle for control of the world famous Russian institution.

item.title: Why North Korea 'has already won'
item.description: Even if the crisis ends right now, North Korea will have succeeded in sending a message across the world: that nuclear weapons make you untouchable, writes Frida Ghitis.

item.title: A beauty beyond skin deep
item.description: As a little girl, she never got a valentine at school parties.

item.title: 'Happy' Gilmore defies surfing cliches
item.description: Forget Point Break's party animals, modern surfing is more about professionalism.

item.title: How suicide shaped mom's gun views
item.description: I am a mother of three, and my views on guns have evolved significantly over the course of my lifetime. My husband hunts and believes strongly in his right to bear arms. But when my 25-year-old son, Peter, shot himself in a moment of despair in April 2012, I came full circle to a harsh reality: There are almost twice as many suicides as murders by firearm across America, roughly 19,000 of the 30,000 gun deaths each year. Yet we disproportionately fear and almost exclusively talk of criminals in the national gun debate.

item.title: Will we care about Web privacy in 2033?
item.description: The launch of the Facebook Home app has reignited the privacy debate over whether the social networking site is becoming too integrated in our lives.

item.title: Psy lightens mood with new single
item.description: As tensions on the Korean peninsula go up, Psy parties down and releases a new music video. CNN's Anna Coren reports.

item.title: Why I fled North Korea
item.description: Hyeonseo Lee says when she was young she thought her country was normal, even though when she was 7 she saw her first public execution.

item.title: Rarely seen North Korea
item.description: The world is used to seeing glitzy military parades from North Korea but defectors paint a very different picture of the country -- one of people making soup out of grass and risking their lives to escape into China.

item.title: Passion took blast victim to Boston
item.description: The graduate student from China crowded around the finish line at the Boston Marathon to cheer on the runners. Tragically she was at the wrong place at the wrong time.

item.title: 'Lone wolf' fears in Boston blast
item.description: In the wake of Monday's bombing that left three dead and scores injured at the Boston Marathon, investigators are scrambling for answers.

item.title: Blast victims: A boy, a fan, a student
item.description: They were standing near the finish line, cheering on the runners in the Boston Marathon. It was a beautiful, cool day when two bombs suddenly unleashed chaos and killed three people. As of Tuesday afternoon, identities of two of the three had been made public.

item.title: Words of support from around world
item.description: Reaction from people in London, Berlin, Madrid, Johannesburg, Nairobi, Rome & Moscow to the Boston Marathon explosions.

item.title: Boston bombings
item.description: A day after the fatal terror attack on the Boston Marathon, authorities warned the city's residents to keep their guard up Tuesday amid a massive investigation to uncover a clear reason for the bombings.

item.title: Tiniest victim
item.description: Almost a year ago, 8-year-old Martin Richard wrote four simple words on a sign at school.

item.title: Iran quake
item.description: A powerful earthquake in southeastern Iran on Tuesday killed several people across the border in Pakistan, Pakistani officials said, but conflicting reports on casualties emerged from Iran.

item.title: Latest N. Korea threat
item.description: North Korea is raising the temperature on its neighbors, saying in its latest threat that it would not give any warning before any attack on South Korea.

item.title: Thatcher's legacy
item.description: People in London step up to CNN's Open Mic and comment on the legacy of Margaret Thatcher.

item.title: Venezuela president
item.description: Opposition candidate Henrique Capriles calls Nicolas Maduro an 'illegitimate president.'

item.title: Dancing bears in India
item.description: Eco Solutions looks at how the inhumane tradition of bear dancing in India is fading out. Mallika Kapur reports.

item.title: Healthy living in Philippines
item.description: A major housing development in the Philippines tries to combine happy and healthy living. Pauline Chiou reports.

item.title: Reef's beauty captured on film
item.description: Doing for our oceans what Google Street View has done on land, a team of marine scientists is building up an extraordinary picture of the world's coral reefs.

item.title: Oceans on brink of collapse
item.description: As the human footprint has spread, the remaining wildernesses on our planet have retreated. However, dive just a few meters below the ocean surface and you will enter a world where humans very rarely venture.

item.title: Our Oceans: Victim or savior?
item.description: My grandfather Jacques Cousteau and my father Philippe dedicated their lives to revealing the ocean's wonders and helping us understand our connection to this vast expanse of water. Their work inspired generations and filled people with awe.

item.title: Modeling Earth's ecosystems
item.description: A group of researchers is building a comprehensive model of the Earth's ecosystems to help predict climate change.

item.title: Robots probe ocean depths
item.description: Despite most humans' land-centric view, Earth is an ocean planet. The global ocean covers more than two-thirds of our planet's surface and makes life as we know it possible: it produces half of the oxygen we breathe, helps regulate our climate and provides the single largest habitat for life on Earth.

item.title: Global warming increases pollen
item.description: With global warming, temperature extremes are becoming a norm -- and that's bad news for allergy sufferers.

item.title: World rejects polar bear plan
item.description: A U.S. plan to give new protection to polar bears was voted down Thursday at an international conference on endangered species.

item.title: Study warns global warming 'epic'
item.description: Global warming has propelled Earth's climate from one of its coldest decades since the last ice age to one of its hottest -- in just one century.

item.title: Environmentalists fill U.S. National Mall
item.description: Marching, dancing and poster-waving environmentalists chanting "Hey, Obama. We don't want no climate drama," packed several blocks on and around Washington's National Mall on Sunday, hoping to spur President Barack Obama to take strong measures against climate change.

item.title: China invites bird flu experts
item.description: Doctors say the discovery of a 4-year-old carrier of the H7N9 bird flu virus who shows no symptoms of the potentially lethal virus is a worrying development that could make the spread of the infection more difficult to monitor.

item.title: Zao Wou-ki: Painting beyond words
item.description: The Chinese-French painter Zao Wou-ki once told me that painting expresses the thoughts we struggle to put into words. Faced with this challenge, "It's easier to learn English!" he joked, his wit shining through, even though Alzheimer's disease had already begun its slow, relentless onslaught on his mind.

item.title: Can China convince Kim to cool it?
item.description: As North Korea's long-term ally, analysts say China has the greatest potential leverage over the country's young leader. But is it likely to assert itself and would Kim Jong Un even listen?

item.title: Chinese travelers turn to rail
item.description: With less than half an hour to spare, Chen Zhu calmly emerged from the subway station connected to the massive Beijing West Railway Station with a small, wheeled bag.

item.title: 'Daily Show' clip goes viral
item.description: A "Daily Show" clip mocking North Korea has gone viral in China.

item.title: China's GDP expected to grow
item.description: Despite concerns about debt and export growth, China's GDP could see some growth this year.

item.title: China tourism surge: Your views
item.description: We knew even while researching Tuesday's feature on the global impact of Chinese tourism that the story was likely to generate strong reactions among readers.

item.title: Chinese teen to tee off at Masters
item.description: The legendary Jack Nicklaus may have won the most titles, a 21-year-old Tiger Woods may have been the youngest champion and Gary Player may have made the most appearances, but a little-known Chinese golfer will be added to the illustrious list of Masters record-holders on Thursday.
